Q: What is the core Stoic idea Marcus repeats throughout Meditations?
ExpA: Control what you can control accept what you cannot
A:
Answer: The core Stoic idea Marcus repeats is that the highest good is to "live according to nature" — i.e., virtue alone is the true good (externals are indifferent), one must bring desires and thoughts under the rule of the will, and consciously work with Providence/God for the common good. ("Such as thy thoughts... such will thy mind be in time" — what the heart is full of, the man will do.)

Q: How does Marcus describe the proper response to insults?
ExpA: They harm the insulter not you remain rational
A:
He says to be kind and loving to all — even to him that hates thee — and to show his error ingenuously and meekly, not by way of exprobation or ostentation of thy patience. Also: do not let little things said or done make thee sorry; at best, suffer patiently if thou canst not suffer joyously.

Q: According to Marcus; why should one avoid seeking praise?
ExpA: Because praise is fleeting and given by those who may not understand virtue
A:
Because praise is ultimately worthless and harmful to the soul. Marcus argues that:
- Praise is fleeting — those who were once commended, and those who commended them, are soon dead and forgotten. You should act for what is good and expedient for the public, not for applause. (bd042120-3fbe-4d7d-94a4-cdf30fe25071)
- Life and fame are short and local — both praiser and praised will soon be "dust and ashes," and praise often exists only in one small corner of the world. (cda382e9-558d-42e7-b12b-99363313b1a2)
- Seeking commendation lets ignorance and a vain desire to please outweigh true prudence; the things praised do not touch the soul. (af904d70-cc47-42a0-a80f-6f629e05813c)
- Worrying about others’ opinions disturbs your own judgment and peace; a man who rightly knows his nature does not look for applause but does good for its own sake. (9c58db4b-bfd9-4cb9-a141-8d8567d7921a; 39cb2bad-24fd-457a-a81c-68c94c76482b)
- In short, “let not thy peace be in the mouths of men” — don’t base your peace on what others say. (dcf1f5fa-37ae-4437-8c4f-f3f25c010f0f)

Q: What effect does reading the play have on its readers?
A:
Reading the play has a powerful, often destructive effect: it rivets and obsessively holds readers ("my eyes became riveted"), can provoke cries of terror or an overwhelming poignant joy and bodily suffering ("I suffered in every nerve"), drives people to hide or destroy the book (flung into the fire), spreads like an "infectious disease" across cities, and becomes taboo—banned, denounced, and rarely discussed aloud (the second part especially avoided).

Q: Why does Publius argue for a large republic?
ExpA: It better controls factions through diversity of interests
A:
Briefly — because a large republic, Publius argues, is better able to produce and sustain “proper guardians” of the public weal:

- A larger society (within a practicable sphere) is more capable of self‑government, and a federal system can extend that practicable sphere (fff4fe40-92ed-4b55-b221-003725607412).
- Unlike a pure democracy (which must be small), a republic can be extended over a large region, so a large republic is feasible (36038119-cda7-4dea-92f9-3f66da828c73).
- A larger republic gives a bigger pool of candidates, so if the proportion of “fit characters” is not lower, the large republic will yield more suitable representatives (66fdeb64-13d0-4ae7-893f-abc6cd764aff; d1e589b1-8403-45d8-bfd0-930d86103b94).
- Representation must be sized to prevent both the cabals of a few and the confusion of a multitude; a properly scaled representative system in a large republic guards against factional domination while remaining manageable (d0b94e48-3837-4b1b-923b-2622a0e65484).
- Practical arrangements (e.g., an appropriate ratio of representatives to inhabitants) can make the House a safe and competent guardian of public interests (10231903-49b6-4358-bf6c-726f129b5dcf).
